titleStmt.title: Despatch from John H. Smyth to John Hay, February 7, 1880

bibl.title: Despatch from John H. Smyth to John Hay
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p:
Consulate Gen'l of the United States,
Monrovia, Liberia, Feb'y 7, 1880.
Mr. J. H. Smyth to the Ass't Sec'y of State.
The arrival of Dutch and English war ships, in the port of Monrovia.

Consulate Gen'l of the United States,
Monrovia, Liberia, Feb'y 7, 1880.
I have the honor to respectfully advise you of the arrival at this port, on the 5th, Feb'y, 1880, the Dutch war ship, Marnix, Commander H. Dyserinck.

At the request of the Commercial Society of Holland, the Secretary of Holland, the Secretary of the Navy, put said ship at the Society's disposal–to call at the port of Monrovia–for coffee plants, to be carried
Hon. John Hay,
Ass't Secretary,
Washington, D.C.
carried to Suriname.

On the evening of the 6th of Feb'y, 1880, the Forester, Commander, Sydney Smith, and on the morning of the 7th Feb'y, 1880, the Boadecia, Commodore Richards, both English war ships, arrived in harbor.
The expressed object in calling was stated to be to present the compliments of Her Majesty to the President, and give renewed assurance of the friendship of Her Majesty's gov't to Liberia.

I am, Sir,
Your obd't serv't,
Jno. H. Smyth,
U.S. Consul General.
